title: Battery tube clip holder for OpenROV

description.text:
These clips provide a way of attaching the OpenROVâ€™s battery tubes to its chassis using a 3D printed â€œsnap-actionâ€ holder. The purpose of the holder is to replace the zip-ties that currently hold the tubes in place.   
I didnâ€™t care for the zip-ties holding the battery tubes because they take fine motor dexterity to tighten and release. Two conditions come to mind that make working with the zip-ties a challenge, wearing gloves and cold weather.  Iâ€™d prefer just a way to â€œsnapâ€ the battery tubes into and out of place.

Required Parts
  • 3D printed battery tube clip holders X 2
  • 3D printed end cap remover X 1
  • 20mm bolts X 2
  • Nuts X 2
  • 1/8th inch drill bit
  • Drill
    • Instructions
  • Print out 3D parts
  • Remove the battery tube zip ties from the front of ROV
  • Drill 1/8th hole on each side of ROV 60mm in from most forward point on bow
  • Thread bolts through each holder and mount to ROV chassis
  • Push battery tubes into each holder

description.text: Sometimes you can't get everything aligned for one print, and you want to assemble it after. This is a slide fit joint I am using to solve that problem. It has an openSCAD file, and so can be added to other openSCAD projects.
I printed these test objects with a .4mm nozzle, 0.8mm wall thickness, and 30% fill. Inland PLA, 210C
This is a way to use Blender to make 3d printable words.

I am using Blender 2.49 presently with a full size keyboard. The long version is to:
First start on a blank page in object mode and press numpad 7 for top-down view.
Then spacebar>add>text.
S(scale)>numpad 50, more or less to make it hefty enough to print.
{F9>}-(bottom of page) Font>Load: c:/Windows/Fonts/ ; center-click on the .ttf you want.(for instance - Frscript.TTF)
Next TAB to edit mode with text selected(A or aa or right click or b or bb).
Backspace to get rid of the word "Text" then type what you want.
Tab to object mode.
Next,with the words selected.(A till all selected): Alt C>Convert font to Mesh.
Tab to edit mode, A to select all, numpad 1 for sideview, E>Region then say like numpad 3 for width>numpad enter.
Now type numpad 7 and see the topdown view.
My printer is .18 x .18 x .12 of the largest square that can be scrolled to, so with that in mind I can Scale, Grab and Rotade to make it all fit. Once you get it sized properly then File>Export>STL The short version is to numpad 7, from object mode space Add>Text, tab to edit mode, backspace 'text'. type in your stuff, tab to oblect mode, scale, Alt-c>mesh, 1, tab, extrude, A-A> ctrl-n to be sure the normals are correct. Then export to STL.

It's a plain candle holder - or? Light the candle and see a secret message appear!  
Possible only by 3D printing, embedded cavities in the walls are invisible in normal lighting but the thinner walls will light up when the internal light source is lit. Use candles with caution, PLA or ABS is not fire proof!

Print in fine resolution. The walls of the embedded messages are 0.8 mm thick to fit a 0.4 mm nozzle, found in e.g. Makerbot MK8. If the message turns out to be readable by artifacts in the surface, you may want to play with e.g. the filament density setting in the slicer software to get it to look better.   
This model should of course be customizable but the fonts in the customizer are currently too horribly looking to suit this kind of model. Until we have a better customizable solution, see this as an idea for own creations. You are of course welcome to use the attached Viacad 2D/3D source file to modify the design.

Looking for a reward for winning a tough league? Don't want to spend a lot? This is what you're looking for. A 3-D printed customizable trophy. Update the text to change year and winners, or simply make one and have it travel over the years. Either way, it'll be a hit in your league. Feel free to contact me with any questions on how to edit it. Open Attribute Editor, then look for textForBevel1 (top line of text) or textForBevel2 (bottom text). https://www.3dphill.com/3d-print-shop/voronoi-steps/#cc-m-product-10980867598

This is a replacement frame for a cheap Ebay Gopro Hero 3 stabilization gimbal. the original version was all metal (aluminum) and I wanted to create a 3d printed version to save weight. Plus add some mods. Specificly a mount for a small FPV video cam and a slot for the accelerometer instead of just having it hot glued to the bottom of the camera platform. I also included a second Plain Camera arm that will use the included Velcro camera lens strap.

UPDATE: After testing I added cable hooks to the base plate. (baseplate3)
UPDATE2: After some flight testing I moved the pivot point on the camera housing so it wouldn't catch against the back motor. The Camera housing will also fit the ISAW action cameras.
Also added some trays to the baseplate.
When you print the gimbal make sre to print (2) of the motor housing cans. They're both exactly the same.

title: In-Door Return Air Pathway
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Passive, in-door or through wall (non-insulated) return air pathway and vent for electronic cabinets, utility closets and bathrooms.

Honeycomb is for sound dampening and reduce air hiss - you may be able to find/use cardboard honeycomb inserts instead...

Print SideA and SideB, sandwich the honeycomb insert between the two. Double sided tape was used on the inside of the flange to mount to the door. You may need multiple units depending on the amount of air-flow needed for the space used - scale as needed. Angled louvers are included if you prefer to use those.

This was sized for a door with a depth of 1 1/3" (~35mm).

This is a hose adapter to couple one size of hose/opening to another.   
The STL file posted here specifically adapts from my Scotchguard (Powered by Bissell) Wet/Dry garage vacuum to the dust exhaust port on my Craftsman 10" bandsaw.  
Use the cutomizer to adjust the sizes or lengths. I have a rostock mini which has a tall print volume, you may need to shorten the two tubes if you have a limited build height. Don't forget about the height of the adapter cone between the two tubes! The total height of the device is: bottomTubeLength + topTubeLength + (bottomTubeLength+topTubeLength)/3   
Or you can download and modify the SCAD file directly.

Print with the small side down. If you adjust the length of either end, make sure that angle of the adapter part is less than 45 degrees. I did not need a brim, but if you make it a lot smaller you may.

comments.text: It gets rid of the relays.  Among other things, this will give you more precise temperature control on your heated build plate.  If you're using a relay to power the heated nozzle, you can switch to this too for the same results.  It will potentially protect your extruder controller - I've had one burn out the heater pins from a short.  The best part, though, is your makerbot will stop clicking like an oven lol.

description.text:
When i rearranged my printers at home my ZYYX printer ended up in a corner and suddenly changing spools became cumbersome. So i designed a spoolholder to mount on the side of the machine to simplify changing spools.
The handle will snap in place and the spoolholder itself which is positioned to the left of the handle is mounted just as the regular spoolholder on the back.

Be aware that if you are using the filament detector this might cause problems, i might add some more parts later to deal with this.

While this is designed to be mounted on the printers right side, you can easily mirror it and make a left side verion.

These are printable parts for an electrostatic field mill design I thought up utilizing a pc case fan brushless motor. Basicly you print them. Cover them with foil and tear apart the fan to get at the magnet ring and fan morot coil. The project also uses some 3mm metal rods from an old CD rom drive. I'll include a pile of step by step photos of it being put together.

This is a printable electrostatic field mill. It allows you to monitor static electric buildup in the atmosphere. It's built from easily obtainable parts any computer geek (like me) should have lying around.
An old pc cpu or case fan (with a 3mm shaft and ball bearings)
a dead cd rom drive (for more 3mm metal rods)
about 2 feet of aluminum foil
some spray adhesive or some other kind of glue.

Print the parts. Collect the parts from the fan and cd rom and follow the pictures. I've tried to put them in the order it should be built.
basically make sure the spinning shutter and the solid ground plane are electrically connected. the middle (sensor plate should be electrically isolated from the rest of the spinning components.
you measure across the sensor plate and the shutter plate to get the readings. I suggest googling field mill. for more information. this was just something I made to see if I could!

description.text: A simple dog-bone (male-male) connector for Thomas- and Brio-compatible wooden train track. This renders in "solid" and "spring" variations. The spring version is the original design but the now-default solid version looks better and actually uses quite a bit less filament (5-15% less for 25-15% infill). To render this shape, you will need tracklib.scad installed in the same directory as this file, or the dotscad/trains repository cloned in its entirety (which will include this file and tracklib.scad). This openSCAD library is part of the dotscad project. Please check there for the latest versions of this and other related files.

author: xansibar

description.text: This is a stamping tool. it has a screw design which allows for multiple heads to be used.

This is a large print, so users of the taz 4 and 5 should not have any problems printing this large object. I'm using the Taz 5 and I just barely got it to fit in one print Quick Tip (watch the initial first layers, mine would hit the limiting switch and printed a straight line on one of the edges...but simply moving the print in the opposite direction in sli3er allowed it to print correctly).

The Bucket Dolly Bowl is the bucket "sleeve" and the Foot is 1 of the 5 total you'll need to make this a complete Dolly. I printed the "sleeve" in one print and then 5 separate prints for the feet.

I needed this for a dust collection system and was sick of the bucket turning over while vacuuming. I know there's simpler solutions but I wanted to take a shot at it. Enjoy!

I printed the bucket holder in one print, and would recommend abs if you don't have issues with abs de-lamination while printing large prints. I had a few cracks of de-lamination in the bucket holder but the feet printed just fine, just a little thin on the edges. Also I did use support on the feet but you might be able to get by without.

I acetone welded the feet to the bucket sleeve. If you use some other print material I think a good quality glue should also do the trick.

The Casters are from Harbor Freight (http://www.harborfreight.com/2-in-clear-polyurethane-light-duty-swivel-caster-69536.html), and the hole in the feet needed to be drilled out just a little for them to fit. I put a little bit of hot glue in the hole before pushing the caster stud in. This should work fine with other 10" bottom 5 gallon buckets, but these Measure Right buckets worked great and I bought those from Lowes
(http://www.lowes.com/pd_161932-84240-PN0040_0__?productId=3734787#BVRRWidgetID)

remixed_from.author: thruit00
remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct v2 for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge / CTC

title: Rear Active Cooling Duct for FlashForge Creator Pro

description.text:
Download version 2 here!

Modified the rear cooling ducts from here and here so that it fits the printer perfectly without hitting anything.

I also orientated the fan mounting position the other way compared to the other two models since the fan I used seemed easier to find online. I used a 24V 50x50x15mm blower fan.

The results turned out great. I can actually see while its printing as opposed to a front cooling duct and have no clearance issues in the rear.

I've attached the SolidWorks (2013) file in case you need to modify it. Please excuse the sloppy modeling techniques. :)

Bill of Materials

  1. 24V 50x50x15mm Blower Fan
  2. 1 x 5.08mm Pitch, 2 Pin Screw Pluggable Terminal Block
  3. 18-24 AWG Wire (in case you need to extend fan wires)

Before Printing
The tolerances where the fan mounts on to are pretty tight since there is not much clearance in the back. I also wanted the fan to fit snugly in the duct for efficiency reasons. Although the fan dimensions should be pretty standard, I recommend printing the BLOWER_MOUNT.stl first to test if the fan you have fits. If not, you can adjust accordingly in the SolidWorks file.

Printing
Must use ABS with this model due to heat considerations being next to the extruder assembly. I printed the inside of the duct and the 2 notches where it mounts onto the printer with supports. You might be able to get away without supports if you already have active cooling. Just note that it is a bit of a pain to remove the supports if you do choose to print with them.

Installation
Once printed, attach fan and mount behind the extruders. I used some 468MP tape to secure it better since it kind of flops around when your print head is moving fast, but it will be fine without it. Will possibly update mount in future revision.

In order to enable the cooling fan you need to connect the fan to the EXTRA_FET port using the 2 pin screwable terminal block. From there you just enable it in your slicer or manually in your gcode.

This is a large zipper pull, including the pull-tabs and slider. I made it to replace a metal zipper that had corroded on my boat. I'm not sure what size it is, but it is on the large side (8.6 mm at the outer edge of the closed zipper). I could not find a replacement at the local fabric store or at a boat canvas shop.

This is made of ABS using Cura with advanced settings using fine parameters. Print it as-is with the small-end down and pull-tabs pointing up. The is little support necessary (use the setting for support only in direct contact table). Use 100% infill to make it strong enough. After printing, use an Exacto Knife to cut loose the pull-tabs on either side of the slider.

Solar Finder for your telescope - clips onto your existing finder-scope, and projects a dot onto the target to tell you when your telescope is solar-aligned.

WARNING: ONLY USE THIS IF YOUR TELESCOPE HAS A FULL-APERTURE SOLAR FILTER OR YOU COULD BLIND YOURSELF!!!!

Note: The part has been completely re-designed to be able to be 3D-printed without support - print it standing up. (This version supersedes my previous "Solar Finder-Scope", which was not well set-out for 3D printing.)

Fit a full aperture solar filter to your telescope, then point your telescope towards the sun - the pinhole casts a bright spot onto the target, to help you align your telescope to the sun.

Depending on the precision / tolerance of your printer, and the accuracy of alignment when it snaps onto your existing finder, the solar dot may or may not hit the centre of the target cross-hairs when solar-aligned, but it should be fairly reproducible between solar viewing sessions (especially if you leave it fixed to the finder-scope rather than removing and re-installing it).

You may need to modify the diameter of the clip to suit your finderscope so that it can just click on. (This is detailed to suit my Celestron Red Dot Finder - OD = 26 mm). Thingiverse files are un-editable "lumps" - a full parametric editable version is hosted as a Public Share on my OnShape Account https://www.onshape.com/ - just search for "Solar Finder Mk 3".

You may need to ream out the pinhole with a drill bit to get a nice clean sun image on the target.

Print it, then clip it onto your existing finder-scope (this version fits a Celestron Red-Dot Finder)

This was modelled in OnShape https://www.onshape.com/, and the native parametric model is shared for Public use - look for "Solar Finder Mk 3" by Julian Hardy.

If you need to modify the design to suit your finder-scope, modify the diameter of the first Sketch "Clip Profile" as required. (This version is detailed to suit my Celestron Red Dot Finder - OD = 26 mm)

(Or you could just scale the model as a whole to get the ID of the clip to suit the OD of your finder-scope.)

Here is another Linear. Had a place where the cases needed to be stronger so it would push and pull. This linear is capable of much heavier pulls than the 31 (5/16") listed in my things. It uses two 3/8" x 7/8" sealed roller bearings instead of the 12mx18mx4m bearings. With a RS555 or 550 motor this linear will pull 10-20 lbs. If you use a metal backing plate to hold it, will probably do more.
Here is a video of the linears working https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6xfDU2BKSvI&feature=youtu.be
Will work with any motor 540-555 with 25mm mounting centers. The motors I am using are Mabuchi RS555PH-23300, 5050 RPM and 380G of tourque, 12-30VDC, 1.25Amp ( available ebay/Parts Express $3.95). You will need a 93 tooth 48P Associated/Arrma type spur gear with the center drilled for the rod and a pinion gear for the motor. Pinion needs to be 12-15 tooth 48P. There is a 93 tooth spur gears you can download and try in the Linear 31 but it won't take much, try adding shells. Also need two 3/8"x7/8"x9/32" sealed bearings, #R6-2RS. Uses 6-32x1" and 3/4" machine screws. Flat heads for inside. Drill the holes to fit.
You can use either 1/4-20 or 1/4-28 all threaded rod and nuts, depending on how much speed you need. The nuts are inserted into the gear halves and sandwiches the gear with #4 screws. Using 1/4-28 will pull harder but slower. Threaded rod has to be anchored on the other end of the linear or hold the rod with nuts at gear and use as a jackshaft.
Just added all kind of different brackets and nose cones so you can have a variety of mounting options. Mount uses 1/4" bolt. You can also use the linear right through a bulkhead if it is a straight pull. There are screw holes to use 4x3/8 sheet metal screws as bearing retainers if you don't need a bracket or nose cone.
Used this linear for the rippers lift motor on my handmade from scratch metal/3D printed 1/6th scale RC Cat D4G Dozer. Linear works great for this application and will push up the back of the dozer that weights 76 lbs. There is a photo gallery of the RC Dozer build on my website http://www.fastmiketanks.com/

Hope you will find many uses, enjoy!

All of the cases and gear halves need to have exterior support to print. The brackets and nose cone should build without support.
To assemble the linear you will need to fit the bearing bores so they go in tight. A drum sander on a drill works good for this. Get the bearings in the cases. Make sure gear halves go inside bearing bores okay, file if needed. You will need to drill out the inside of the gear halves for clearance so the rod goes through freely("F", "G" or "H" ). Take the gear halves and insert the nuts in both sides. Sandwich the gear between the halves. Some gears will need holes drilled for the screws. Use 4x1/2 or 3/4" screws to hold gear halves. If stuff doesn't turn straight, turn the halves an 1/4 turn until you get a good matchup and turns straight and mark them so they go back together this way with gear. To get the best results go ahead and screw the rod into the nuts with it all together. Make sure there isn't any play back and forth with the nuts inside. If there is shove the nut farther down in its hole and do again until no/little play, but gear spins freely on rod.
To put the linear together mount the case half to whatever side you are mounting to, so you can tighten screws from the inside( use 6-32 or 4m flat head screws and lock nuts if needed). Set the gear in the case and put the other case half over it. Use (4) 6-32 x 1" or 1.25" round head machine screws on the outside to hold cases together.
Be sure everything turns freely, switch gear around 180 if hitting screws or file down so turns easy.
Install the motor and pinion gear. The motor takes short 3mm button head bolts. Adjust for good gear to gear clearance.
If you plan to mount it in a bulkhead or make a metal holder, the cases have a square bolt pattern from a 1.4" diameter circle, so each hole is .7" from the center. The holes are .160" through the case. I used 4mm flatheads from my slash parts with nylock nuts, but 6-32 flatheads will work also.
If you find something wrong or needs changes drop me a line.

author: CallJoe

description.text:
This thing has been replaced by this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753227

A bolt together modular tank style robotics platform!

I use this with my students. They get the base kit, then they customise.

I have run these with Arduino, Raspberry Pi and Intel Galileo, both in autonomous and controlled drone mode.

These tanks are very versatile and it is easy to create bolt on accessory holders as you need. I will post the accessories I have created here from time to time.

https://youtu.be/RU1G50hiegI

THERE ARE SOME BASIC ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE IMAGE GALLERY. YOU NEED TO VEIW THEM IN FULL SCREEN.

BASE TANK PRINT:
2 x Track Inner Frames
2 x Track Outer Frames
1 x Base Fram
1 x Upper Frame (You can do more of these)
6 x Cog

PRINTING TRACKS:
Different printers and different filaments produce different results, so I have uploaded a range of tracks with different pin holes. Essentially I print the at 50% infill and print the smallest hole diameter I can. If I need to loosen the tracks, I then print a few larger diameter holed tracks.

MOTORS:
I use the generic motors linked below and install 4 of them:

http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1X-for-Arduino-Smart-Car-Robot-Plastic-Tire-Wheel-with-DC-3-6V-Gear-Motor-New-/131459704359?hash=item1e9b9be627

I use this motor shield to drive them:

http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Dual-H-Bridge-Stepper-Motor-Drive-Controller-Board-Module-For-Arduino-L298N-TG-/181687932010?hash=item2a4d71d46a

PUTTING IT TOGETHER:
I used M3 bolts to put it all together. The motors need to go in before you bolt the track frames onto the base frame.

I use 30mm brass standoffs to put the top frame (and any other stuff that I want) on

The tracks need 2mm dimeter wire (or bamboo skewers). They need to be loose enough to spin freely without being too loose. Aim for the tracks to sag about 10mm when suspended in mid air.

ACCESSORIES:

  • Arduino Uno Holder - holds the Uno - also the Mega with a lot of overhang.
  • Base Tray - fits into the base frame. Holds stuff.
  • Base Tray for L298N - Holds an L298N Motor Shield
  • Battery Case - Two rechargeable 9V batteries in parallel can be held in this case and can motor this bot along nicely. The higher the mAH rating the better.
  • Breadboard Holder - for 1/2 sized Breadboard
  • LCD Holder - Holds standard 2 x 16 Char LCD screen
  • LED Bracket - Headlights for LED Chips - You'll need to also print a brace for the back. Don't let them get hot or they melt through to print!
  • Light Bar - A bar for front/back that holds 5 x 5mm LEDs
  • Mini Pan/Tilt Servo Holder - Holds a Pan Tilt Kit from Adafruit (or similar)
  • Raspberry Pi Holders - 2 different orientations for your Pi
  • Sharp Infrared Distance Sensor Holder - holds Sharp 2Y0A02 Infrared distance sensor
  • Static RPi Camera Holder - Holds a Raspberry Pi camera at 90 degrees to horizontal

comments.text: One additional issue with the cheaper motors...they will very possibly have significantly different levels of friction within the gearbox.   I bought 2 generic robot sets off ebay that each included 2 motors. Which means that "going forward" for the bot meant "veer to the right"

comments.text: Batteries: If you look in the accessories files - you can print a battery box and clip that fits into the base. It is designed to hold 2 x 9V batteries which I tend to wire up in parallel to get a bit more power out of them. I use 2 x 500mAh Li rechargeables (Which are actually 8.4V) and will run the bot for about 30-40 minutes (depending on what you are doing). If you use normal 9V batteries it won't work as well as they do not give consistent power output out and the Bot controller (Raspberry or Arduino) will restart if the motors all of a sudden need to do more work.

Flip Flop or tumbling blocks is a folk toy consisting of blocks of wood held together by strings or ribbons. The tumbling blocks folk toy, also known as Jacob's Ladder dates back to the Pilgrim times in America.

Know you can 3d print yours
No assemble required
Prints Standing Up
Print more sections to make it longer
The more you play with it the better it works.

Play with your printing settings and the "thingOne" and "thingTwo" pieces until your prints move freely, reduce the extruder multiplicator to makes hinges move easily (mine was at 87% on this print) use 0% infill.
After Printing, cut the small "supports" that connect the "blocks" to each other. Swing free moving back and forward each hinge, and work your way trough the hole piece.

description.text:
I designed this quadcopter frame to be easily printed using PLA, and to fit the motors + board from a Syma X1 quadcopter.

The arms are strangely long, but here's the thing: the Syma X1 circuitry doesn't like flying small frames. You get a lot of wobble if you reduce the dimensions much from the original. So I had to make the arms longer to reduce the wobble. The wobble was killing me.

If you want to access the original parametric design, which would allow you to change dimensions such as motor or board size, it is available from Onshape right here.

I print this using Simplify3D, with a layer height of 0.3 mm in PLA, with about 15% infill.

I've attached the Simplify3D print profile so you can just import that if you use Simplify3D already (you should, it's great). It's the file called "Explo Makerbot 5th Generation Print Settings.fff"

I'm currently using these replacement motors that I found on Amazon. They say they're for a Hubsan X4 H107L, but those motors fit right into a stock Syma X1 as well. In my experience those Teras last a bit longer and the end caps are less likely to pop. But any motor with 7x20mm and a 1mm shaft diameter will work as a drop-in replacement. One of these days I'm going to try these babies, which look excellent and are universally reviewed to be the best.

description.text:
This is my first experience with OpenSCAD and was made as an experiment, if anyone finds it useful then that's a bonus!
This is a derivative work of A cube by imaterialise.
A hypercube is a "shadow" or projection of a 4 dimensional cube in 3d space; much like if you projected a 3d cube onto a 2d surface. If you're interested in the theory behind this then please consult wikipedia as I don't really understand it... looks cool though ;).
I have parameterised this to enable customisation of the size of the inner and outer cubes and the thickness of the "lines" for the inner and outer cubes. You will also notice that the polyhedrons connecting the two cubes have triangular cross-sections; this was mainly for ease of coding (less polygons to orientate!), but also seemed neat to me at the time. (note: this is my first OpenSCAD thing so I'm not sure about the neatness and robustness of my code so any feedback would be greatly apreciated!)

• Input parameters to the top of the code where indicated
  • Compile and generate g-code
  • Print and clean up
    • I don't know if this thing is actually printable as I'm still a way off finishing my RepRap (but I suspect a smaller overall dimension will give a better print). If anyone fancies giving it a go then that would be fantastic! As ever feedback is greatly appreciated. Note: printing a true 4D cube will require a 4D printer and extra-dimensional perception (not included);).

A mount for attaching the Fatshark 600TVL FPV camera to the Armattan Morphite 180 frame. The camera is angled 20 degrees upward.

This mount includes 26mm posts for attaching the full Armattan top plate, you will need 6 other 26mm standoffs.

The .scad file is included for your convenience.

It should print as oriented with your default settings. No support necessary.

This requires the new longer top plate from Armattan. It replaces the front two standoffs. I used 26mm standoffs, that is the minimum to allow for the 20 degree tilt. I used threaded rod that I cut to 38mm and two M3 nylon lock nuts. If you have some 38mm or 40mm bolts and nylocks, those would probably work better.

If you are not using the full top plate, you could probably remove the tops of the standoffs in your slicer and mount from the bottom only.

A zip tie is used to attach the camera to the mount.

My Morphite consists of the following set up.

  • DYS 1804 2300KV motors
  • Nanotech 4S 850Mah batteries
  • HQprop 4045 bullnose props
  • DYS SN20A ESCs
  • Afromini FC
  • Hawkeye 600mW 5G8 vtx
  • FrSky D4R-II R/C receiver
  • Micro MinimOSD
  • Fatshark 600TVL camera
  • Pololu 5V step-down regulator

This is a super fast/powerful setup, highly recommended!

I designed this x-carriage because it was always a major pain to pull apart the hotend/extruder/x-carriage assembly to do any work on it.

The micro x-carriage is split up in two pieces. One part keeps the belts tensioned even when the extruder/hotend has been removed. The other part lets you remove the extruder/hotend base simply by removing 3 screws.

As long as you have connectors on all your wires, you can easily swap out extruder/hotend combos.

The extruder/hotend base uploaded here is really just a template that can be modified later. It can be used as a starting point for adding mounting holes, etc for whatever extruder/hotend/etc you want.

This is the 2.0 micro x-carriage. The belt baseplate has been beefed up in the center to prevent bending like the v1 tended to do. The other major change is that the belt clamps are now a beefed up left/right pair w/ a little groove where you can tuck back any excess belt.
Download the extruder_base_minimal.fcstd file, import it into FreeCAD, take a look at it for dimensions, etc. and modify it or create a new one to match whatever extruder/hotend combo you have.

title: MakerGear M2 LocLine Raspberry Pi Camera mount for OctoPrint OctoPi or Astroprint

description.text:
I'm using OctoPrint to run my MakerGear M2. I wanted to be able to mount the Pi in a position that gives a good view of the part so that I could remotely monitor it. The mounts that I found on Thingiverse were fairly large or tended to hold the camera in a bad position or both. This mount is very simple, just two small pieces so that it prints quickly and it works with readily available 1/4" LocLine (buy the genuine stuff, not the Asian ripoff). The Pi/Camera can be easily positioned in any orientation and it doesn't wiggle around. The base piece is held to the frame of the MakerGear with a single M3 screw, one washer and one Nylok nut. The VESA mount is secured to the RasPi case with (4) 3mm screws and Nylok nuts. I printed the mounting post (base) in ABS and the X-shaped part in PLA. The nut recesses are intentionally a little snug so that the nuts don't fall out. For the VESA part, just give each a gentle squeeze with pliers to seat them. For the other piece, use the M3 screw with washer to draw then nut into its hole. Then gently remove the screw without displacing the nut. Snap it onto the locline then position on machine and tighten nut without knocking it out of its hole. It's very easy, more trouble to describe than to do. ENJOY.

Works with these stunningly beautiful Raspi Cases:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608169

Genuine LocLine is available for cheap on Amazon if you don't have any:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006R9O3HE?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00

comments.text: The vesa mount to locline adapter is too small to fit the locline.  I've tried EXTREME force and it still won't snap in.  The locline adapter that mounts on the printer frame is perfect.  I've tried ABS at 100% and 100.5% but no joy.  Any advice?
comments.author: greenhornet

comments.text: It all depends on how your printer prints in a given material.  I printed this part in PLA (the mount that attaches to the printer I did in ABS because it stays-put better), my printer prints PLA outside dimensions to-size and inside dimensions tend to be about 0.015 too tight.  I printed just the socket a couple of times to get the fit that I wanted, then printed the whole thing.  I am using genuine Loc-Line and I also assemble it using the Loc-Line pliers.  You do need a tight fit so that the raspi doesn't sag over time.  Mines still working very well.  If you slice just the socket, you can experiment with different scaling factors then print the whole thing when you have it how you like it.  A small change has a big effect, I'd be surprised if you have to go beyond maybe 101 or 102%.  The STL as-uploaded printed on my machine at 100% in PLA for a perfect fit.  HTH, c
comments.author: greenhornet

comments.text: I printed in PLA and it fits perfectly.  I have a feeling you didn't account for ABS shrink.  Have you tested your design with ABS?

This is a large coin bank. It prints in one piece, and can only be opened by breaking it apart. It is 120 mm tall and 115mm in diameter. The coin slot is 28 x 2.5 mm and has been tested with coins in the United States.

Let's be honest, this is a difficult object to print. It looks deceptively simple. You have to get your slicer settings just right, or it won't work. The main difficulty is that it is hollow and has a 36 degree overhang (where 90 deg is straight up, no overhang). You can't use supports, since there is no way to remove them from the inside.

Print it with one side of the pentagon on the build platform, and the coin slot vertical. Then use 0.10 mm layers. One outline (shell, perimeter, or whatever). And 100% infill with the pattern at 45 degree angles to the walls of the bank. Then slow the print down to as slow as you have patience for.

If you use more outlines, or don't have your infill at a 45 degree angle to the walls, the the top of the print will not turn out well. Structurally the overhang will not hold together well.

The 100% infill is required for strength. The walls of this bank are just 2 mm thick, but it has no problems standing up to the weight of a full load of coins.

The Banks in the photos took me 24.25 hours to print, each, on a highly modified Replicator 2. I have printed them in as little as 14 hours, but they don't look as nice.

Good luck!

This drill ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731086 ) reminded me of a pump top I had when I was a kid, so I built one.

Updated: see end note.

Action video (no knob version): https://vid.me/MiuW
And a virtually unedited version with dishwasher noise, smacking it across the kitchen floor: https://vid.me/R6JD

The piece here is printed in ABS and I had some cooling artifacts, but at a 10 hour print rate, I'm going to accept that for now. It uses a lot of plastic because there is some hidden thickness printed at a 90% fill rate on the lower wide part of the top. This weighted ring allows it to keep it's momentum for long spins, and the low center of gravity keeps it fairly stable. You can see this in the cutaway view picture.

Variations on the screw drive
There are two versions of the screw drive. One has cylinder at top on which you can glue the knob after assembly. It looks nice, but it adds weight high up and tends to induce wobble. I printed my knob hollow. If you look at the layers in your slicer, you're likely to find that one side will have more weight than the other due to uneven distribution of fill. Go hollow.

The other version of the drive screw just has a little nub you can grip, but falls down just below the surface of the bell housing. Less wobble. To get it out, just invert the top and gravity will extrude it.

Bell housing bearing lubrication
In the bell housing, there is a ring bearing to minimize friction between the top of the bell and the toothed drive when pulling up the drive screw. After a few uses though, you might find that it sort of sticks causing two problems: the friction slows down the rotation of the top and it can even lift the top. This can be remedied by spreading a little vegetable oil on your finger, and lubing up that ring. That will allow the disc to spin freely when pulling up the drive screw.

0.5mm Nozzle
My printer (Lulzbot Mini) has 0.5mm nozzle and the STL files are optimized for that. This means that if you have 0.4 or 0.35mm nozzle, the screw holes, bell housing attachment holes, and the friction fit between the bell housing and drive ring might be too loose. I have included the source files (made in freeCAD, which, as the name suggests, is free, just google it). I've labeled the various parts so it should be fairly obvious to see which parts need editing. You would probably have to modify the tap for the screw drive as well, otherwise it would be a bit too loose. You can do that by making the square that defines the tap a little bit smaller.

Screws
I used six screws in this design to attach the drive mechanism to the body of the top. Nice tiny self-tapping screws are a little hard to find, these are what I used ($5 for 1000): http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GMQDSRI Of course you can just drill out the holes to fit whatever you have on hand.

Making your own top body
I've included a topCore.stl file to make it simpler to make your own body for the top in whatever program you prefer. There is a photo showing the dimensions of this inner core to use as a guide when designing your own.

Note
I consider this a remix because the inspiration was the drive mechanism of the pump drill, although I needed to recreate the screw drive to make it a little beefier and a lot longer. Turns out that was a good experience -- I'm pretty much a newb with CAD, but when I was watching it print, I noticed it was just a square rotating along the Z axis. With that tidbit, it was nothing to make a square, and sweep that square along a helix. Saved me from having to figure out how to deal with modifying STL files, which is way less straightforward than I ever imagined.

Update
The transmission disk has been updated. After some use, it would tend to stick when pulling up the pump-screw and the friction would make operation difficult. I made some cuts in the top and side of the disk to reduce suction effects. So far it seems to work better. This change is reflected in the files:

pumpTop-transmission.stl
pumpTop5-1.fcstd

author: beerwinespirits

description.text:
This is a drag chain for the MakerBot extruder cable (or any other cable/wires).
It keeps your extruder cable out of the Z-stage belt and let your MakerBot look professional (kind of...)
The objects need very detailed printing in order to work. You definitely want a good tuned MakerBot and Skeinforge settings to print this (don't say I didn't warn you!).
The ZIP file contains GCode files for all objects, including 6 or 8 chain links on one raft. It might be the best to skeinforge the gcode with your own, tuned settings. The included GCode files worked for me (resp. my MakerBot), but  (again): these are some really hairy objects to print.

• Print as many chain links as you need or like. For the extruder cable on my Makerbot I use 12 links.
  • If you insert a standard patch cable (like the extruder cable which came with the MakerBot batch 5 kits), you shouldn't need any additional closing mechanism. If you insert only a few wires, print out one or more "Closing Sticks". Cut the stick into pieces and use the notch in the chain links to hold the wires inside the chain.
  • If your extruder cable is mounted upright (default, when using the MK3 Plastruder), you sholdn't need any special end link. If your extruder driver card is mounted horizontal (like mine in the photos), print the optional "End Corner Extruder" piece. Use this piece as last link on the extruder side and tape it to the RJ45 jack (see photo). Clip the flat part if needed.
  • To mount the drag chain to the MakerBot body (or elsewhere), print the "Chain Anchor" piece. It has holes for using the upper Z endstop bolts to mount it to the outside of the body. Then just use the notch on the last chain link to attach the drag chain to the anchor.

Goes on the sides of 5th gen makerbot replicators to help hold the tape down.
Creates a home for your iPhone and cable on the bedside table. This is a replica of the Distilunion Snooze Alarm Dock for iPhone 4 (http://www.distilunion.com/products/snooze_iphone-alarm-dock).

***I've added a new version that is closer to the original design. First time I've copied something from an image. It looked basic enough so the only issue was getting the dimensions for the iPhone right. It could do with some tightening up, but I like the chunky look. I designed on tinkerCad and the resultant STL has been run through NetFabb. ReplicatorG used for slicing with following settings: Supports - None
Object infill - 10%
Layer hight - 0.34
Number of shells - 1
Feedrate - 40
Travel rate - 56
Print temperature - 230 Printed on Makerbot Replictor 2. Turn the design on its end to print so there are no supports or over-hanging parts for the printer to get hung up on.

comments.text: I just thought I should mention... This part has a gap of 0.15mm between gears. I suspect most people printing this with their Prusa i3's most likely haven't fine-tuned their machines yet, since a spool solution is generally one of the first things printed. For that reason, you might want to check out the original design and make one to the same measurements as this one, but raise the gear gap to 0,25mm.. Just a suggestion otherwise the gears could be fused together lol.
